com.spazedog.lib.rootfw3.extenders

Class FileExtender.File

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.spazedog.lib.rootfw3.extenders.FileExtender.File
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    ExtenderGroup
    Enclosing class:
    FileExtender

    public static class FileExtender.File
extends java.lang.Object
implements ExtenderGroup
    This is kind of an extension of File, only this does not just come with a lot more tools, it also switches to the root/shell whenever a file operation is not possible using the regular applications permissions.
    Note that this implements the ExtenderGroup interface, which means that it does not allow anything outside RootFW to create an instance of it. Use RootFW.file(String) to retrieve an instance.

        public FileExtender.FileData readMatches(java.lang.String match,
                                java.lang.Boolean firstMatch)
        Search the file line by line to find a match for a specific pattern and return all of the matched lines.
        It is also possible to have it stop at the first found match.
        Parameters:
        match - The pattern to search for
        firstMatch - Whether or not to quit on the first found match
        Returns:
        All of the matched lines wrapped in a FileExtender.FileData object
        See Also:
        readOneMatch(String)

      • write

        public java.lang.Boolean write(java.lang.String[] input,
                      java.lang.Boolean append)
        Write data to the file. The data should be an array where each index is a line that should be written to the file.
        If the file does not already exist, it will be created.
        Parameters:
        input - The data that should be written to the file
        append - Whether or not to append the data to the existing content in the file
        Returns:
        True if the data was successfully written to the file, False otherwise

      • remove

        public java.lang.Boolean remove()
        Remove the file. Folders will be recursively cleaned before deleting.
        Returns:
        True if the file was deleted or did not exist to begin with, False otherwise

        Returns:

      • move

        public java.lang.Boolean move(java.lang.String dstPath)
        Move the file to another location.
        Note that moving the file, will not change this objects file pointer. This means that if the move was successful, this object will point to a file that no longer exist. So in order to continue working with the file, you will need to change the pointer to point at the new location. You can use openNew(String) or RootFW.file(String).
        Parameters:
        dstPath - The destination path
        Returns:
        True on success, False otherwise

      • rename

        public java.lang.Boolean rename(java.lang.String name)
        Rename the file.
        Note that since renaming is actually the same as moving (Both is actually just renaming the path), the rules in move(String) also apply here. In order to continue working with the file after renaming it, you will need to change the pointer to point at the new location, as this object will point to a file that no longer exist. You can use openNew(String) or RootFW.file(String).
        Parameters:
        name - The new name to use
        Returns:
        True on success, False otherwise

      • copy

        public java.lang.Boolean copy(java.lang.String dstPath)
        Copy the file to another location.
        Parameters:
        dstPath - The destination path
        Returns:
        True on success, False otherwise

      • extractFromResource

        public java.lang.Boolean extractFromResource(Context context,
                                    java.lang.String asset,
                                    java.lang.String permissions,
                                    java.lang.String user,
                                    java.lang.String group)
        Extract data from an Android Assets Path (files located in /assets/) and add it to the current file location. If the file already exist, it will be overwritten. Otherwise the file will be created.
        Parameters:
        context - An android Context object
        asset - The assets path
        permissions - Permissions to add to the file
        user - The owner to add to the file
        group - The group to add to the file
        Returns:
        True on success, False otherwise

                                    java.lang.Integer resourceid,
                                    java.lang.String permissions,
                                    java.lang.String user,
                                    java.lang.String group)
        Extract data from an Android resource id (files located in /res/) and add it to the current file location. If the file already exist, it will be overwritten. Otherwise the file will be created.
        Parameters:
        context - An android Context object
        resourceid - The InputStream to read from
        permissions - Permissions to add to the file
        user - The owner to add to the file
        group - The group to add to the file
        Returns:
        True on success, False otherwise

      • openParent

        public FileExtender.File openParent()
        Open a new FileExtender.File object with the parent of this file.
        Returns:
        A new instance of this class representing the parent directory

      • openCanonical

        public FileExtender.File openCanonical()
        If this is a link, this method will return a new FileExtender.File object with the real path attached.
        Returns:
        A new instance of this class representing the real path of a link

      • getCanonicalPath

        public java.lang.String getCanonicalPath()
        Get the canonical path of this file or folder. This means that if this is a link, you will get the path to the target, no matter how many links are in between. It also means that things like /folder1/../folder2 will be resolved to /folder2.
        Returns:
        The canonical path

      • getAbsolutePath

        public java.lang.String getAbsolutePath()
        Returns the absolute path. An absolute path is a path that starts at a root of the file system.
        Returns:
        The absolute path

      • getResolvedPath

        public java.lang.String getResolvedPath()
        Like getCanonicalPath(), this will resolve any /folder1/../folder2 and rewrite it as /folder2. Unlike getCanonicalPath(), this will not resolve any links. It will only rewrite and return a more clean version of the current path.
        Returns:
        The absolute path

      • getPath

        public java.lang.String getPath()
        Returns the path used to create this object.
        Returns:
        The parsed path

      • getParentPath

        public java.lang.String getParentPath()
        Returns the parent path. Note that on folders, this means the parent folder. However, on files, it will return the folder path that the file resides in.
        Returns:
        The parent path

      • getName

        public java.lang.String getName()
        Returns:
        The name of the file

      • getDetails

        public FileExtender.FileStat getDetails()
        Get information about this file or folder. This will return information like size (on files), path to linked file (on links), permissions, group, user etc.
        Returns:
        A new FileExtender.FileStat object with all the file information

      • getDetailedList

        public FileExtender.FileStat[] getDetailedList()
        See Also:
        getDetailedList(Integer)

      • getDetailedList

        public FileExtender.FileStat[] getDetailedList(java.lang.Integer maxLines)
        This is the same as getDetails(), only this will provide a whole list with information about each item in a directory.
        Parameters:
        maxLines - The max amount of lines to return. This also excepts negative numbers.
        Returns:
        An array of FileExtender.FileStat object

      • getList

        public java.lang.String[] getList()
        This will provide a simple listing of a directory. For a more detailed listing, use getDetailedList() instead.
        Returns:
        An array with the names of all the items in the directory

      • getObjectList

        public FileExtender.File[] getObjectList()
        This is the same as getList(), only this will provide an array of FileExtender objects for each item in the directory.
        Returns:
        An array of FileExtender objects

      • fileSize

        public java.lang.Long fileSize()
        Calculates the size of a file or folder.
        Returns:
        0 if the file does not exist
